searchDocs.title: Binary
searchDocs.content: Binary Binary - Binary comes from the Latin bini-, meaning having two parts. In programming, binary often refers to the base-2 number system which consists of only the digits zero and one.

searchDocs.title: Byte
searchDocs.content: Byte Byte - A byte consists of eight bits and is the smallest addressable unit of memory in a modern computer.

searchDocs.title: CPU
searchDocs.content: CPU CPU - A CPU or central processing unit is hardware optimized to execute instructions in series

searchDocs.title: Concurrent
searchDocs.content: Concurrent Parallel / Concurrent - In programming, parallel refers to the processing of data simultaneously, meaning at the same time.

searchDocs.title: GPU
searchDocs.content: GPU GPU - A GPU or graphics processing unit is hardware optimized to execute instructions in parallel.

searchDocs.title: Decimal
searchDocs.content: Decimal Decimal - Decimal comes from the Latin deci-, meaning tenth. Decimal refers to the base-10 number system which consists of the digits zero through nine.

searchDocs.title: Bit
searchDocs.content: Bit Bit - A bit is a binary digit, which is the smallest unit of information. A bit may only occupy one of two states at a time. A bit can either be zero or one, low or high, off or on, false or true respectively.

searchDocs.title: Grammar
searchDocs.content: Grammar Grammar - In programming, grammar refers to how the symbols of a programming language are arranged.

searchDocs.title: Hardware
searchDocs.content: Hardware Hardware - Hardware are the physical components that comprise a computer.

searchDocs.title: Memory Address
searchDocs.content: Memory Address Memory Address - A memory address is a binary number (usually 32 bits wide or 64 bits wide), which describes the physical location of a chunk in memory. It is less efficient to address individual bits so a computer's memory is broken into chunks called bytes where each byte has its own address.

searchDocs.title: Hexadecimal
searchDocs.content: Hexadecimal Hexadecimal - Hexadecimal comes from the Latin hex- meaning six and deci- meaning tenth. Hexadecimal refers to the base-16 number system which consists of the numeric digits zero through 9 and an additional six alphabetic digits; A, B, C, D, E, F.

searchDocs.title: Memory
searchDocs.content: Memory Memory - Memory is a term describing how computers store information, usually in the form of bits and bytes.

searchDocs.title: HDD
searchDocs.content: HDD HDD - An HDD or hard disk drive is a kind of persistent storage device that stores information on a spinning disk using a magnetic head to Because the disk has to be physically moved to read or write to certain locations, an HDD is not a form of random access storage.

searchDocs.title: Parallel
searchDocs.content: Parallel Parallel / Concurrent - In programming, parallel refers to the processing of data simultaneously, meaning at the same time.

searchDocs.title: Octal
searchDocs.content: Octal Octal - Octal comes from the Latin oct-, meaning eight. Octal refers to the base-8 number system which consists of the digits zero through seven.

searchDocs.title: Persistent Storage
searchDocs.content: Persistent Storage Persistent Storage - Persistent storage is a kind of memory that does not require active power to store information, meaning that persistent memory can survive a power cycle. Persistent memory is usually slower to read than volatile memory.

searchDocs.title: ODD
searchDocs.content: ODD ODD - An ODD or optical disk drive is a kind of persistent storage device that stores information on a spinning disk using a laser. Because the disk has to be physically moved to to read or write to certain locations, an ODD is not a form of random access storage.

searchDocs.title: Programming Language
searchDocs.content: Programming Language Programming Language - A programming language is a set of grammar and syntax used to write programs.

searchDocs.title: Random Access
searchDocs.content: Random Access Random Access - Random access means that read operations take the same time regardless of their location in memory.

searchDocs.title: Program
searchDocs.content: Program Program - A program is a sequence of instructions written to be executed by a computer.

searchDocs.title: Read
searchDocs.content: Read Read - In programming, reading refers to the process of copying a value from memory to the CPU.

searchDocs.title: RAM
searchDocs.content: RAM RAM - RAM or random access memory is a kind of volatile memory that stores information via electric switches. Because there are no moving parts or magnetic switches, RAM is incredibly fast.

searchDocs.title: Series
searchDocs.content: Series Series / Serial - In programming, serial refers to the processing of data sequentially, meaning one at a time.

searchDocs.title: SSD
searchDocs.content: SSD SSD - An SSD or solid state drive is a kind of persistent storage device that stores information via magnetic switches. Because there are no moving parts, an SSD is a form of random access storage.

searchDocs.title: Serial
searchDocs.content: Serial Series / Serial - In programming, serial refers to the processing of data sequentially, meaning one at a time.

searchDocs.title: Software
searchDocs.content: Software Software - Software are the programs that a computer executes.

searchDocs.title: Syntax
searchDocs.content: Syntax Syntax - In programming, syntax refers to the symbols that comprise a programming language. A syntax error occurs when a symbol is unrecognized or used incorrectly.

searchDocs.title: Volatile Memory
searchDocs.content: Volatile Memory Volatile Memory - Volatile memory is a kind of memory that requires active power to store information, meaning that volatile memory cannot survive a power cycle. Volatile memory is typically faster to read than persistent storage.

searchDocs.title: Write
searchDocs.content: Write Write - In programming, writing refers to the process of copying a value from the CPU to memory.
